verse: King Solomon loved many ·women who were not from Israel [foreign women]. He loved the daughter of ·the king of Egypt [Pharaoh], as well as women of the Moabites, Ammonites, Edomites, Sidonians, and Hittites [Prov. 5–7].

The Lord had told the ·Israelites [sons/children of Israel], “You must not ·marry people of other nations [or associate with them; come into them, and they must not come into you]. If you do, they will cause you to ·follow [turn your hearts to] their gods.” But Solomon ·fell in love with these women [clung/held fast to them in love].

He had seven hundred wives who were from royal families and three hundred ·slave women who gave birth to his children [concubines; a secondary wife of lower status than a primary wife, but higher than a common servant]. His wives ·caused him to turn away from God [led him astray; turned his heart away].

As Solomon grew old, his wives ·caused him to follow [led him astray after; turned his heart away after] other gods. ·He did not follow the Lord completely [His heart was not wholly devoted/faithful to the Lord his God] as ·his father David had done [the heart of his father David had been].
Solomon ·worshiped [followed; went after] Ashtoreth, the goddess of the people of Sidon, and ·Molech [Milcom], the ·hated [detestable] god of the Ammonites.
So Solomon did ·what the Lord said was wrong [evil in the eyes/sight of the Lord] and ·did not [refused to] follow the Lord completely as his father David had done.

On a hill east of Jerusalem [the Mount of Olives], Solomon built two ·places for worship [high places; 3:2]. One was a place to worship Chemosh, the ·hated [detestable] god of the Moabites, and the other was a place to worship Molech, the ·hated [detestable] god of the Ammonites.
Solomon did the same thing for all his foreign wives so they could burn incense and offer sacrifices to their gods.
The Lord had appeared to Solomon twice, but the ·king [his heart had] turned away from following the Lord, the God of Israel. The Lord was angry with Solomon,
because he had ·commanded [warned] Solomon not to follow other gods. But Solomon did not ·obey [observe; keep] the Lord’s command.

So the Lord said to Solomon, “Because you have chosen to break your ·agreement [covenant; treaty] with me and have not obeyed my commands, I will tear your kingdom away from you and give it to one of your ·officers [servants].
But I will not take it away ·while you are alive [in your days] ·because of my love for [for the sake of] your father David. I will tear it away from [the hand of] your son.

I will not tear away all the kingdom from him, but I will ·leave [give] him one tribe to rule. I will do this ·because [for the sake] of David, my servant, and ·because [for the sake] of Jerusalem, the city I have chosen.”
The Lord ·caused [raised up] Hadad the Edomite, a member of the royal family of Edom, to become Solomon’s ·enemy [adversary].
Earlier, David had defeated Edom. When Joab, the commander of David’s army, went into Edom to bury the dead [Israelite soldiers], he ·killed [slaughtered] all the males.
Joab and all the Israelites stayed in Edom for six months and ·killed [exterminated; eliminated] every male in Edom.
At that time Hadad was only a young boy, so he ·ran away [fled; escaped] to Egypt with some of his father’s ·officers [servants].

They ·left [set out from] Midian and went ·to Paran, where they were joined by other men [or with men from Paran]. Then they all went to Egypt to see Pharaoh the king, who ·gave [assigned] Hadad a house, some food, and some land.
·The king liked Hadad so much [Hadad became such a great favorite of Pharaoh that] he gave Hadad a wife—the sister of Tahpenes, the king’s wife.
·They had [She bore for him] a son named Genubath. Queen Tahpenes ·brought him up [raised; or weaned him] in the royal palace with ·the king’s [Pharaoh’s] own ·children [or sons].

While he was in Egypt, Hadad heard that David ·had died [lay down/slept with his fathers/ancestors] and that Joab, the commander of the army, was dead also. So Hadad said to the king, “Let me go; I will return to my own country.”
“Why do you want to go back to your own country?” the king asked. “What ·haven’t I given you here [do you lack with me]?”
God also caused another man to be Solomon’s ·enemy [adversary]—Rezon son of Eliada. Rezon had ·run away [fled] from his master, Hadadezer king of Zobah.

After David ·defeated [slaughtered; massacred] the army of Zobah, Rezon gathered some men and became the leader of a ·small army [marauding band; gang of rebels]. They went to Damascus and settled there, and Rezon ·became king of [took control of] Damascus.

Rezon ruled Aram, and he ·hated [abhorred; despised; was hostile to] Israel. So he was an ·enemy [adversary] of Israel all the ·time Solomon was alive [days of Solomon]. Both Rezon and Hadad made trouble for Israel.

Jeroboam son of Nebat was one of Solomon’s ·officers [servants]. He was an Ephraimite from the town of Zeredah, and he was the son of a widow named Zeruah. Jeroboam ·turned [rebelled] against the king.

This is the ·story [account] of how Jeroboam turned against the king. Solomon was ·filling in the land [building the terraces/Millo; 9:15] and ·repairing [closed the gap/breach in] the wall of Jerusalem, the city of David, his father.

Jeroboam was a ·capable [energetic] man, and Solomon saw that this young man was ·a good worker [industrious]. So Solomon put him over all the ·workers [labor force; or forced labor] from the tribes of Ephraim and Manasseh.
One day as Jeroboam was leaving Jerusalem, Ahijah, the prophet from Shiloh, who was wearing a new ·coat [cloak], met him on the road. The two men were alone out in ·the country [a field].
Ahijah took his new ·coat [cloak] and tore it into twelve pieces [representing the original twelve tribes of Israel].
Then he said to Jeroboam, “Take ten pieces of this coat for yourself. The Lord, the God of Israel, says: ‘I will tear the kingdom away from ·Solomon [Solomon’s hand] and give you ten tribes.
But ·I will allow him to control [he will have] one tribe. I will do this for the sake of my servant David and for Jerusalem, the city I have chosen from all the tribes of Israel.

I will do this because ·Solomon has [they have] stopped following me and has worshiped the Sidonian goddess Ashtoreth, the Moabite god Chemosh, and the Ammonite god ·Molech [Milcom]. Solomon has not ·obeyed me [walked in my ways] by doing what ·I said is right [is right in my sight/eyes] and obeying my laws and commands, as his father David did.

“‘But I will not take all the kingdom away from ·Solomon [his hand]. I will let him rule all ·his life [the days of his life] ·because [for the sake of] of my servant David, whom I chose, who ·obeyed [observed; kept] all my commands and laws.
But I will take the kingdom away from his ·son [son’s hand], and I will ·allow you to rule over [give you] the ten tribes.

I will ·allow Solomon’s son to continue to rule over [give to his son] one tribe so that David, my servant will always have a ·descendant [lamp before me; possibly a metaphor for the reign of a king] in Jerusalem, the city where I chose to ·be worshiped [put my name].
But I will make you ·rule [reign] over everything you ·want [desire]. You will ·rule [be king] over all of Israel,

and I will always be with you if you ·do what I say [walk in my ways/paths and do what] is right. You must obey all my commands. If you obey my laws and commands as David did, I will be with you. I will ·make your family a lasting family of kings [build you an enduring house/dynasty], as I did for David, and give Israel to you.
I will ·punish [afflict; humble] David’s children because of this, but I will not ·punish [afflict; humble] them forever.’”
Solomon tried to kill Jeroboam, but he ·ran away [fled] to Egypt, to Shishak king of Egypt, where he stayed until Solomon died.
Everything else King Solomon did, and the wisdom he showed, ·is [is it not …?] written in the book of the ·history [acts] of Solomon.
Solomon ruled in Jerusalem over all Israel for forty years.
Then he ·died [lay down/slept with his fathers/ancestors] and was buried in the City of David [Jerusalem], his father. And his son Rehoboam ·became king [reigned] in his place.
